isis.stitle: International® T 444E Diesel Engine - Model Years Late 1997 to 2003 - Crankcase, Crankshaft, Connecting Rods, And Pistons - Connecting Rods, Pistons and Piston Rings - Bearing Fitting Procedure For Old Style Connecting Rod

svcproc.title: Bearing Fitting Procedure For Old Style Connecting Rod

caution.para: To avoid engine damage, do not attempt to reduce journal-to-bearing running clearances by reworking the bearing cap and/or the bearings. Regrind or replace the crankshaft only.

calloutgroup.callout1: Diameter at Open Ends Before Bearing Crush Load
Diameter at Open Ends After Bearing Crush Load

svcproc.para: Bearing shells must fit tightly in the bore. When bearing shells are inserted into the connecting rod and cap, they protrude slightly above the parting surface. This protrusion is required to achieve a bearing crush.

Across the open ends, bearing shells are slightly larger than the diameter of the connecting rod bore into which they are assembled. This condition is designed into the bearing shell, causing it to spread outward at the parting line when a bearing crush load is applied by tightening the nuts. Some snap may be lost in normal use, but bearing replacement is not required because of a nominal loss of snap.
When the assembly is drawn up tight, the bearing is compressed, ensuring a positive contact between the backside of the bearing and the machined surface of the connecting rod bore.

step1.para: Install new bearing shells in the connecting rod and in the bearing cap. Lubricate each shell with clean engine oil.
Install the connecting rod on the crankshaft.
Install the bearing cap on the connecting rod. Tighten the nuts or bolts on the bearing cap alternately and evenly to the special torque value.

figure.caption: Measuring Bearing Running Clearance With Plastigage®

step1.para: Measure the bearing running clearance as follows:

step2.para: Remove the bearing cap. Wipe the oil from the face of the bearing shell in the bearing cap and the exposed portion of the crankshaft.
Place a piece of undamaged Plastigage® across the full width of the bearing shell about 6 mm (0.25 in) from the center of the bearing cap.
Install the bearing cap and tighten the nuts or bolts alternately and evenly to the special torque value.

note.para: Do not turn the crankshaft. This will smear the Plastigage®.

step2.para: Remove the bearing cap. The Plastigage® material will adhere to either the bearing shell or the crankshaft. Do not remove the Plastigage®.

Use the Plastigage® scale to measure the widest point of the flattened material. The numbers within the graduated marks on the wrapper/scale indicate the running clearance in thousandths of an inch or millimeters. See the specifications for the correct running clearance.
Remove the Plastigage® material. Repeat the test for each connecting rod bearing.

note.para: With the use of precision bearings, few problems should be encountered. However, if proper running clearance is not achieved, a problem with the crankshaft may still exist. Regrinding the crankshaft and using undersize bearings are probably necessary.
Also, the bearing cap bolt torque is very important. Use a torque wrench that is known to be accurate. Repeat the running clearance check procedure before condemning the crankshaft.

figure.caption: Checking the Connecting Rod Side Clearance with a Feeler Gauge

step1.para: Measure the connecting rod side clearance using one of the following tests:
Feeler Gauge TestPry two adjacent connecting rods apart and use a feeler gauge to measure the clearance between them. Refer to the specifications and repeat for all connecting rods.

step2.para: Place the tip of the dial indicator on the connecting rod bearing cap.
Pry the two connecting rods apart with a screwdriver or prying tool. Then zero the dial indicator.
Pry the connecting rod in toward the dial indicator while recording the connecting rod side clearance. Refer to the specifications and repeat for all connecting rods.

note.para: Lack of side clearance could indicate a damaged rod or a bearing that is out of position. Too much clearance may require replacement of the rods or crankshaft.
